name: Harshit Sanghvi
tagline: Grad Student at New York university
body:
### Introduction
Harshit is a graduate student at New York University, studying Computer Science, with current GPA of 3.83. He is actively seeking Software Engineer Intern position for Summer 2015 and Full-Time position starting Spring 2016.

He has 4.5+ years of professional experience as Software Developer and is skilled in multiple programming languages and software development methodologies. He is also familiar with different programming paradigms such as Functional programming, Procedural programming and Object-oriented programming.

Some of his achievements include improving Nokia Networks’ HSUPA products’ user capacity to 2X and also co-inventing a US patent describing the algorithm. Recently, he played a major role in launching university wide Web Publishing service based on WordPress for all of NYU's Global Community of 300,000 users. 

To keep himself updated with latest technical advancements, he spends considerable time reading technology blogs and magazines and also maintain his own technical blog at [G33kopedia](g33kopedia.wordpress.com).

### Honours & Publications
##### [Block Scheduling Method For Scalable And Flexible Scheduling In A HSUPA System](http://www.google.com/patents/US20140126481)
`United States US20140126481` `Issued May 8, 2014`

* A method for block scheduling of users is described. The method includes, in response to determining that a number of users in a wireless network exceed a threshold number, allotting the users into k block. The value of k is at least two. For each block, the method performs determining residual information for the block. The method also includes, for each block of the k blocks, loading into a fast-access memory user data for users in the block and scheduling the block in a scheduling period based at least in part on the user data and the residual information for k−1 other blocks.

##### [Block processing techniques to scale scheduler operation in Cellular Systems: A case study for 3G networks](https://www.slideshare.net/secret/6fKjv3pmyII3zc)
`TAIST Tokyo Tech Program, National Science and Technology Development Agency (NSTDA)` `January 25, 2013`

* While the capabilities of modern cellular systems are being rapidly enhanced by standards groups such as 3GPP LTE and IEEE 802.16, the limiting factor in performance has shifted to platform constraints such as processing load and memory. In this paper we investigate techniques to overcome these limitations and to achieve the theoretical predictions of system capacity. In particular we focus on the scalability of scheduler operation in High Speed Uplink Packet Access (HSUPA) systems. HSUPA is fast becoming the technology of choice for both operators and end-users with wide-spread deployments. However, scaling the capacity of HSUPA systems without significant hardware upgrades remains a difficult proposition. In this work we propose a novel method to enhance cellular capacity manifold without disruption to Quality-of-Service (QoS).
